item.content:encoded:
I was asked on Twitter why Python uses 0-basedÂ indexing,â€¦

è€çˆ¹å½“å¹´ä¹Ÿå¾ˆæ˜¯ç§¯ç´¯ä½¿ç”¨ G+ çš„, å…¬å¼€å›ç­”äº†å¾ˆå¤šä»·å€¼é—®é¢˜â€¦Â èƒ½çœ‹ä¸€çœ¼å°‘ä¸€çœ¼äº†â€¦

èƒŒæ™¯Â¶

Google+ å¸å·å°†äº 2019 å¹´ 4 æœˆ 2 æ—¥å…³åœã€‚ä¸‹è½½ Google+ å†…å®¹å¯èƒ½éœ€è¦ä¸€äº›æ—¶é—´ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¯·åœ¨ 2019 å¹´ 3 æœˆ 31Â æ—¥ä¹‹å‰å¼€å§‹ä¸‹è½½ã€‚

å‘ç°Â¶

Guido vanÂ Rossum

å…¬å¼€

2013å¹´10æœˆ23æ—¥

I was asked on Twitter why Python uses 0-based indexing, with a link to a new (fascinating) post on the subject (http://exple.tive.org/blarg/2013/10/22/citation-needed/). I recall thinking about it a lot; ABC, one of Pythonâ€™s predecessors, used 1-based indexing, while C, the other big influence, used 0-based. My first few programming languages (Algol, Fortran, Pascal) used 1-based or variable-based. I think that one of the issues that helped me decide was sliceÂ notation.

Letâ€™s first look at use cases. Probably the most common use cases for slicing are â€œget the first n itemsâ€ and â€œget the next n items starting at iâ€ (the first is a special case of that for i == the first index). It would be nice if both of these could be expressed as without awkward +1 or -1Â compensations.

Using 0-based indexing, half-open intervals, and suitable defaults (as Python ended up having), they are beautiful: a[:n] and a[i:i+n]; the former is long forÂ a[0:n].

Using 1-based indexing, if you want a[:n] to mean the first n elements, you either have to use closed intervals or you can use a slice notation that uses start and length as the slice parameters. Using half-open intervals just isnâ€™t very elegant when combined with 1-based indexing. Using closed intervals, youâ€™d have to write a[i:i+n-1] for the n items starting at i. So perhaps using the slice length would be more elegant with 1-based indexing? Then you could write a[i:n]. And this is in fact what ABC did â€” it used a different notation so you could write a@i|n.(See http://homepages.cwi.nl/~steven/abc/qr.html#EXPRESSIONS.)

But how does the index:length convention work out for other use cases? TBH this is where my memory gets fuzzy, but I think I was swayed by the elegance of half-open intervals. Especially the invariant that when two slices are adjacent, the first sliceâ€™s end index is the second sliceâ€™s start index is just too beautiful to ignore. For example, suppose you split a string into three parts at indices i and j â€” the parts would be a[:i], a[i:j], andÂ a[j:].

So thatâ€™s why Python uses 0-basedÂ indexing.

æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹Â¶

ç®€å•è¯´,Â å°±æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†åˆ‡ç‰‡æ—¶çš„è¯­ä¹‰åˆç†æ€§â€¦
